title: Getting around
body: To help you tailor the course to your preferences, we've broken the content down into short topics. You're able to filter what you see on the menu and pin the things you find most helpful.
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: The way you want
_items.body: Use the filter menu at the top left of the page to organise the content on the screen by completion status, bookmarked items or sections of interest.

_items.title: Bookmarking
_items.body: If you find something you like or want to save it for later, you can pin it to your menu by selecting the pin icon. The filter menu at the top left allows you to display pinned items only.

_items.title: Dashboard
_items.body: To help track your progress throughout the topics, in the top right of the screen you will have access to the dashboard. This dashboard is a useful tool that can tell you how you're tracking and will give you guidance on your progress.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body: Use the Resources menu at the top right of the page to explore further resources available in this course.

title: A world of possibilities
body: Whether you're thinking local or global, the Monash Doctoral Program will support your research journey and professional development so you emerge ready to make the greatest possible impact.
instruction: Select Play to hear from our Vice Chancellor.

title: What's in this course
body: Let's take a look at what's involved in completing this course.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Straight to the point
_items.body: Each topic has been broken down into small, focused learning bites using video, graphics and web articles. Scroll down the menu page to find the topic you want, then use the navigation arrows to cycle through the learning bites. You can explore the topics in any order, but we suggest you start with 'Communicating matters' and work your way through.

_items.title: Want to know more?
_items.body: We've incorporated additional resources to help you develop your communication skills further. These include quick reference guides, documents and web articles with extra insights into effective communication. You can access them via the Resources menu at the top right of the page. This reading is estimated to take approximately 30 minutes and can be included in your professional development hours.

_items.title: The next steps
_items.body: We want you to think about how you can build skills for the 21st century – communication being one of them. That's why this course includes a Communication Development Plan (CDP). It's a critical component of your course, which once completed, will need to be given to your supervisor for review and sign-off. Download and save the CDP from the Resources menu. We'll refer you to CDP activities throughout this course, which need to be completed offline. It's estimated that these activities will take approximately 90 minutes and can be recorded as part of your professional development hours.

title: Communication – a skill you need
body: Communication skills are identified by the Foundation for Young Australians as one of the most important and in demand skills to employers – at the heart of a 'new work mindset'. Why are communication skills important to you now and in the future?
instruction: Select Play to find out.

title: Make your communcation count
body: Everyone wants to make an impact on other people when they communicate their ideas, thoughts or findings. Building your communication skills will help you present your findings at conferences and seminars, write your thesis, publish your work and write applications for funding.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more about the power of your communication.

_items.title: Build positive relationships
_items.body: Want to get more out of each interaction? Interested in enhancing your impact on colleagues, supervisors and other stakeholders? Communication is the key. Learning to engage people in the right way and creating positive encounters will build and foster positive relationships and networks.

_items.title: Innovate
_items.body: Great communicators drive innovation. Learning to openly communicate and present new ideas, improves your ability to cooperate and innovate. Taking the time to communicate your ideas with impact, increases the likelihood of your idea being implemented to its full potential.

_items.title: Be a team player
_items.body: There are times when you're not just writing your thesis. You may be collaborating with other researchers on publications, planning programs of undergraduate teaching, or working as part of a research or industry team. Strong, open communication within a team tends to boost morale and allows a team to work more cohesively and effectively.

_items.title: Negotiating
_items.body: Need to negotiate a deadline with your supervisor? Want to get funding approved? Learning to communicate effectively and influence others will help you carry out your research, access resources and negotiate with colleagues, funding bodies, the University administration and external stakeholders.

title: Breaking down the barriers
body: We each use a communication style that we have developed over the years. Our personality, experiences, education, work and home environments, as well as our role models will have shaped this style. However, our instinctive/native approach may not always lead to the best results. Which of the following would you consider to be barriers in effective communication?
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: When trying to explain something, I ask my listeners if they're following me.
I get so caught up in what I have to say that I'm unaware of the expressions and reactions of others.
I find it difficult to express my opinions when others don't share them.
When I don't understand a question, I ask for another explanation.
I become defensive when I'm being criticised.
When I know what the other person is going to say I answer right away.

_feedback.correct: That's right. Dismissing another's point of view, not offering feedback or providing inappropriate responses can lead to confusion, mistakes, disagreements and unnecessary conflict. Learning effective communication techniques will help you overcome these and other communication barriers. Wherever your future lies, communicating with impact will maximise your success. Explore another topic to learn more about successful communication.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Dismissing another's point of view, not offering feedback or providing inappropriate responses can lead to confusion, mistakes, disagreements and unnecessary conflict. Learning effective communication techniques will help you overcome these and other communication barriers. Wherever your future lies, communicating with impact will maximise your success. Explore another topic to learn more about successful communication.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Dismissing another's point of view, not offering feedback or providing inappropriate responses can lead to confusion, mistakes, disagreements and unnecessary conflict. Learning effective communication techniques will help you overcome these and other communication barriers. Wherever your future lies, communicating with impact will maximise your success. Explore another topic to learn more about successful communication.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: What works?
body: What makes for good communication? Is it just the words we use? Good communication is made of many factors. Everything from how we say things, our ability to listen and the way we respond to others. When you ask people to define good communication, their responses will vary.
instruction: Select Play to hear what some of our graduate researchers think?

title: Elements of communicaton
body: To become a good communicator, it's important to know the elements of communication. So, what are the key components in the communication process?
instruction: Select the icons to find out.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out.

_items.title: Communicator
_items.body: The sender, speaker, issuer, or writer who intends to convey or transmit a message. Are you the communicator? Before communicating the message, it's a good idea to consider what you are doing, why you are doing it, how you should do it and what you expect the result to be.

_items.title: Message
_items.body: The subject matter of the communication. What does the communication involve? What is its purpose? What information will be included? How much detail will it include?

_items.title: Transmission
_items.body: The act of conveying the message, verbally or non-verbally. Verbal communication includes written and oral communication. Non-verbal communication, or body language, includes facial expressions, eye contact, body posture, gestures, tone of voice, touch, etc.

_items.title: Channel
_items.body: The medium used to transmit the message. How would you communicate the findings of your research? You could use traditional academic channels, like journal articles, texts, conferences or reports. Or perhaps 'old' media, such as newspapers, magazines, radio and television. And of course there's the 'new' media, like web pages, blogs and social media.

_items.title: Receiver
_items.body: Who is the message meant for? Who will be reading your report? Who will be listening to your presentation? Take into consideration the factors that might affect the behaviour of the intended receiver or audience.

_items.title: Response
_items.body: How did the receiver reply or react? Did they have any questions? What was the result of the communication? Did you achieve your objectives?

title: The right message
body: The communicator is the person delivering the message. Their message is what they produce and use – their presentation, email, article, paper or report. Before sending a message it's a good idea to consider what will make it clear and complete.
instruction: Select each heading to find out.

_items.title: Understandable
_items.body: We don't want to confuse our listeners or readers. Use language that is straightforward and easy to comprehend. Follow a logical and coherent sequence. This reduces misunderstandings and allows the right message to come across.

_items.title: Clear
_items.body: What's your story? Why does it matter? Why now? A clear message has a well-defined purpose or objective, and avoids ambiguity. It's specific and concrete about what it wants to achieve and what actions you want the receiver to take.

_items.title: Adequate
_items.body: Is the core information there? Incomplete information can cause misunderstandings, problems and serious consequences. A complete message contains sufficient information to serve the purpose of the communication.

_items.title: Appropriate channel
_items.body: Good communication uses the right channel mix. It takes into account the nature of communication, urgency of communication, audience preferences and geographic considerations.

_items.title: Accurate
_items.body: Is it accurate? False and misleading statements may do damage to your reputation or the reputation of the organisation or university you represent. Consider the quality of your evidence and use correct facts and figures.

_items.title: Courtesy
_items.body: Is your message courteous, respectful and polite? People tend not to respond well to people that are rude. Is it friendly, open, and honest? Courtesy implies taking into consideration both viewpoints, as well as the feelings of the receiver.

title: The way we communicate
body: What channels do you use to communicate? Communication comes in many shapes and forms. You might be interested in publishing your research as a series of journal papers. Maybe you're keen to enter a Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition. You may be aiming to have a poster at a big national conference or start a blog related to your research. Consider the scenarios below and choose the most appropriate channel to deliver the message.
instruction: Select your response from the options below and select Submit.

_items.text: Your research findings are complex and may stir up some emotions.
You want to create interest in a topic quickly and reach as many people as possible.
You need to send quick project updates to your industry partner.
You want to incorporate visual graphics and extended written content.

_feedback.correct: That's right. It pays to stop and think, and select the most appropriate channel – one that encourages a specific behaviour or outcome. If your message is complex, face-to-face channels are best because they allow for interaction and opportunities to clarify ambiguity. Email, internet and social media platforms are less personal, but are efficient in relaying a message one-on-one or to a large group. If your message doesn't require much of a response from the receiver, written communication should be used to provide all the relevant information. Now it's time to select your CDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Your communication choices.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. It pays to stop and think, and select the most appropriate channel – one that encourages a specific behaviour or outcome. If your message is complex, face-to-face channels are best because they allow for interaction and opportunities to clarify ambiguity. Email, internet and social media platforms are less personal, but are efficient in relaying a message one-on-one or to a large group. If your message doesn't require much of a response from the receiver, written communication should be used to provide all the relevant information. Now it's time to select your CDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Your communication choices.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. It pays to stop and think, and select the most appropriate channel – one that encourages a specific behaviour or outcome. If your message is complex, face-to-face channels are best because they allow for interaction and opportunities to clarify ambiguity. Email, internet and social media platforms are less personal, but are efficient in relaying a message one-on-one or to a large group. If your message doesn't require much of a response from the receiver, written communication should be used to provide all the relevant information. Now it's time to select your CDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Your communication choices.

title: Communicate to connect
body: Good communicators connect. They go about communicating in a way that promotes shared understanding, and shows respect for their audience. How do you communicate to connect?
instruction: Select Play to find out.

title: Tips to connect
body: What were some key behaviours that Emily and Lisa discussed? What did they think would help Lisa connect with her audience?
instruction: Select one or more from the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Ask questions to gather more details
Use facial expressions and gestures to convey the message
Encourage others to express their ideas
Rephrase key points to confirm understanding

_feedback.correct: That's right. All the above behaviours would help you connect. They promote a shared understanding and show respect for the listener. Using these techniques increases the odds that what you have to say, the message they you're trying to deliver, will have relevance and impact. What do you think? How would you describe a good communicator? Open your CDP to complete the activity: The good communicator.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. All the above behaviours would help you connect. They promote a shared understanding and show respect for the listener. Using these techniques increases the odds that what you have to say, the message they you're trying to deliver, will have relevance and impact. What do you think? How would you describe a good communicator? Open your CDP to complete the activity: The good communicator.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. All the above behaviours would help you connect. They promote a shared understanding and show respect for the listener. Using these techniques increases the odds that what you have to say, the message they you're trying to deliver, will have relevance and impact. What do you think? How would you describe a good communicator? Open your CDP to complete the activity: The good communicator.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: What do good communicators do?
body:
Good communicators:

  • Treat others how they'd like to be treated
  • Recognise preferred forms of communication
  • Think before speaking
  • Listen before talking or typing
  • Ask questions to better understand
  • Are aware of non-verbal behaviour
  • Are professional in handling differing points of view
  • Are open to new ideas or contributions
  • Don't commit to things they don't want to, or can't do
  • Recognise that emotions may be at play.

Want to know more. Select the What do good communicators do? document from the Resources menu. This delves more into the above communication skills and attributes.

title: The non-academic audience
body: You need to be able to communicate with non-academic audiences and researchers in other fields. However, bridging the gap between societal and academic discourse is often a challenge. Communicating the relevance of your research and what you really want, particularly to non-academic audiences, is important. Why?
instruction: Select Play to hear from our expert.

title: The curse of knowledge
body:
Do you suffer from 'the curse of knowledge'? It might not always feel like it, but your knowledge of your field is beyond that of most people. To the outside world, you're becoming an expert. However, it's easy to fall prey to 'the curse of knowledge' – a cognitive bias that occurs when people are unable to ignore the knowledge they have when predicting the interests or behaviours of others.

Brothers Chip and Dan Heath, experts in effective communication, have written about this issue in their article. Select 'The curse of knowledge' from the Resources Menu to learn more.

title: Meet trang
body:
Trang is a graduate student investigating a chemical reaction with an industry partner. She finds it difficult communicating the relevance of her deep scientific knowledge, and her insights into the commercial world, to potential employers and collaborators that aren't directly involved in her field.

Which of the following do you think will help her communicate and connect with her non-academic audience?
instruction: Select one or more from the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Tell a story
Use scientific terms that will impress
Use a real case study
Use concrete language
Use specific language
Use a lecture style format

_feedback.correct: That's right. Trang needs to turn quite complex issues into straightforward communication. The more specific, particular, real and tangible her communication, the more likely her research will resonate with a non-academic audience. Effective communication avoids jargon and general, vague, or abstract language, which can confuse or patronise your audience. What will you do to communicate the relevance of your research and ensure it connects with your audience? Open your CDP to complete the activity: What's your research story?

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Trang needs to turn quite complex issues into straightforward communication. The more specific, particular, real and tangible her communication, the more likely her research will resonate with a non-academic audience. Effective communication avoids jargon and general, vague, or abstract language, which can confuse or patronise your audience. What will you do to communicate the relevance of your research and ensure it connects with your audience? Open your CDP to complete the activity: What's your research story?

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Trang needs to turn quite complex issues into straightforward communication. The more specific, particular, real and tangible her communication, the more likely her research will resonate with a non-academic audience. Effective communication avoids jargon and general, vague, or abstract language, which can confuse or patronise your audience. What will you do to communicate the relevance of your research and ensure it connects with your audience? Open your CDP to complete the activity: What's your research story?

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: The right focus
body: One of your goals as a graduate researcher is to make meaningful connections with your audience. This involves thinking beyond your own research and taking into consideration your audience's perspective.
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: Research centric
_items.body: Do you adopt a 'research centric' approach? Many people spend time talking at length about their project, their research and themselves, without taking the time to understand their audience or to explore the potential relevance of their work to the broader community.

_items.title: Audience centric
_items.body: Do you put the audience at the centre of your research story? Do you focus on what directly matters to them, their needs, wants and desires? In an audience centric approach, the audience determines the research content, language used and the outcomes and expectations.

_items.title: Meet in the middle
_items.body:
How do you bridge the gap between research and audience centric communication? Challenge yourself to think more simply and develop an open mind set every time you communicate. Take time to explore:

  • Your audience(s) – who do you want to reach and connect with?
  • Your message(s) – what you might say that connects?
  • The outcome(s) – what are you are trying to achieve and why are you connecting?

title: Make the connection
body: Are you focused on your audience or your research? How do you work to connect the two? Let's see our graduate researchers in action.
instruction: Select Play.

title: The analysis
body:
What do you want from the audience? You may want to provide them information about your findings, consult with them regarding your research, ask them questions or involve them in a project. To do this effectively you need to know how they are likely to feel about and react to your idea, project or report. You also need to know how best to engage them and communicate with them.

Which of the following questions are key to analysing your audience?
instruction: Select one or more from the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: What interest do they have in the outcome of your work?
What motivates them?
What information do they want from you?
What will win them around to support your project?
How will you manage their opposition?
How do they want to receive information from you?
What is their current opinion of your work?

_feedback.correct: That's right. Answering these questions and others like these will help you adapt your message so that your listeners and readers will respond. Apart from these questions think about the demographics of your audience (their age, gender, culture and educational level). Also, their attitude, beliefs and values and how they'll impact your message. Visit your CDP to complete the activity: Research that connects.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. All these questions and others like these will help you adapt your message so that your listeners and readers will respond. Apart from these questions think about the demographics of your audience (their age, gender, culture and educational level). Also, their attitude, beliefs and values and how they'll impact your message. Visit your CDP to complete the activity: Research that connects.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. All these questions and others like these will help you adapt your message so that your listeners and readers will respond. Apart from these questions think about the demographics of your audience (their age, gender, culture and educational level). Also, their attitude, beliefs and values and how they'll impact your message. Visit your CDP to complete the activity: Research that connects.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Work on your S.P.I.N.
body: What's S.P.I.N.? It's a conceptual framework that helps you think about your message in a structured way and in a way that connects. S.P.I.N. may be used in various situations. It's a useful tool to help you think through how to communicate ideas, your research, requests for funding, etc.
instruction: Select the icons to find out more about S.P.I.N.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more about S.P.I.N.

_items.title: Situation
_items.body: Start with determining the situation or context surrounding your research. Context gives your research meaning and direction. This stage is about identifying the wider context before jumping into the details. It makes the why of your research clear.

_items.title: Problems
_items.body: Next, communicate the real-world problems, challenges (or opportunities) that might arise because of this situation. Communicating the problems highlights the implied need of your research.

_items.title: Implications
_items.body: From this, communicate the implications or effects of these issues. Why the problem or opportunity you have described matters and needs to be addressed?

_items.title: Need
_items.body: Only when you have communicated, S.P. and I., do you lunge into N. Time to communicate what you're doing or intending to do that helps address the issues and overcome the implications you have described – the need that exists, and the focus of your research.

title: What goes wrong?
body: Have you ever had a conversation with someone where you had absolutely no idea what they were talking about? Communication often goes off track because its purpose and direction isn't clear. Without a plan, the message fails to pack a punch and the relevance isn't clear.
instruction: Select each heading to learn where researchers may go wrong.

_items.title: Observation #1
_items.body:
When communicating, people tend to talk about themselves – what they want, what they're researching, what facilities they have access to. For instance:
  • "My research investigates a new technique for studying the mating behaviour of parrots."
  • "I'm working in a lab studying a particular type of protein in wheat."
  • "I'm researching the portrayal of heroes in early American literature."

_items.title: Observation #2
_items.body:
Sometimes people ignore, or fail to consider audience interests. The may use language that audiences are unfamiliar with or fail to demonstrate the relevance of the research. For instance:
  • "Bowl systems occur in loose groups used by a number of males as traditional courtship areas and are unrelated to feeding or nesting."
  • "While monomeric gluten proteins (gliadin) show viscous behaviour, polymeric gluten proteins (glutenin) are elastic."
  • "American heroes have been depicted in literature since the seventeenth century. Essentially, the depictions are stereotyped, pejorative, and unauthentic."

_items.title: Observation #3
_items.body:
As a result of the first two observations, audiences often switch off, minds wander, and the communicator fails to make the most of the opportunity – they fail to connect. Leaving researchers thinking:
  • "I think it went straight over their head, they didn't seem that interested in my research into bowl systems used by the Kakapo Strigops habroptilus of New Zealand."
  • "I think my talk fell flat, I found it difficult to connect – I was trying to explain about the importance of monomeric gluten proteins but it all got a bit technical."
  • "Most of the literature I spoke about, the audience had never heard of – I'm starting to question the relevance of my research."

title: Bringing S.P.I.N. to life
body: By using S.P.I.N. and exploring ways to connect, you can become more relevant and achieve greater impact. Select the arrow to see some examples of communicating with impact.

title: Bringing S.P.I.N. to life
body: "This image shows a rare New Zealand parrot, they're amazing creatures that some of you may have heard about. My research is helping scientists, governments and conservationists learn how to better protect this species, and it also has broader relevance to other endangered species in New Zealand and elsewhere."

title: Bringing S.P.I.N. to life
body: "How many of you love the smell and taste of fresh bread in the morning? My research is helping us better understand the proteins in wheat that give bread dough its elasticity – helping to make better, nicer bread for people who are gluten intolerant. That's millions of people around the world."

title: Bringing S.P.I.N. to life
body: "Who has not become fascinated by American politics of late, the presidential campaign and America's standing in the world? My research explores American heroes, and how these have changed over time. It helps make sense of why particular personality types and personas resonate, and what this means in the modern age – with potential relevance to governments, organisations and anyone interested in leadership today."

title: The value of S.P.I.N.
body:
Becoming familiar with S.P.I.N. is a valuable exercise as the framework can be applied to help you structure many different types of communications.

Think about your research and career aspirations. In which situations would S.P.I.N. be useful for you?
instruction: Select one or more from the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Elevator pitch
Grant applications
Interviews
Three Minute Thesis (3MT) presentation
Funding pitch

_feedback.correct: S.P.I.N. can help you develop your elevator pitch – a 30 second spiel on what you're doing. It can help you structure grant applications to compellingly communicate the importance of a project, how it aligns with government priorities, and the implications if the project is or isn't funded. It can assist you to 'think on your feet' during career interviews. Are you an entrepreneur? It can help develop your ideas and funding pitches. Whether you're presenting to leadership or executive teams or preparing for a 3MT presentation, S.P.I.N is the tool for you.

_incorrect.final: S.P.I.N. can help you develop your elevator pitch – a 30 second spiel on what you're doing. It can help you structure grant applications to compellingly communicate the importance of a project, how it aligns with government priorities, and the implications if the project is or isn't funded. It can assist you to 'think on your feet' during career interviews. Are you an entrepreneur? It can help develop your ideas and funding pitches. Whether you're presenting to leadership or executive teams or preparing for a 3MT presentation, S.P.I.N is the tool for you.

_partlyCorrect.final: S.P.I.N. can help you develop your elevator pitch – a 30 second spiel on what you're doing. It can help you structure grant applications to compellingly communicate the importance of a project, how it aligns with government priorities, and the implications if the project is or isn't funded. It can assist you to 'think on your feet' during career interviews. Are you an entrepreneur? It can help develop your ideas and funding pitches. Whether you're presenting to leadership or executive teams or preparing for a 3MT presentation, S.P.I.N is the tool for you.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: S.P.I.N. in action
body: Working with S.P.I.N. is about asking the right questions when preparing to communicate. This will significantly increase the likelihood of you meeting your communication objectives. For example, the right questions could speed up the process, whereas the wrong questions could stall it or even halt it completely.
instruction: Select Play to see how graduate researchers are putting a S.P.I.N. on their research.

title: Ask the right questions
body: Michael Marquardt wrote an insightful book called <cite>Leading with Questions</cite>, his premise being that too often when we prepare to communicate we make statements when we should be asking questions. Thinking about communicating your research using S.P.I.N is made easier by asking yourself the right types of questions.
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: Situation questions
_items.body:
Take a step back from your research and think about the following questions:
  • What societal trends or issues might your research relate to?
  • What key facts and insights can you identify relating to the status quo?
  • Relating to these topics, what might be of interest to your audience?

_items.title: Problem questions
_items.body:
Relating to these trends and the status quo (the situation) consider:
  • What problems or challenges might exist?
  • What are the limitations, current responses or gaps in knowledge?
  • Of these issues, are any particularly relevant (important or of interest) to your audience and research?

_items.title: Implication questions
_items.body:
Why do these problems matter to the audience:
  • If nothing is done, what is likely to happen? What will we miss out on?
  • If the challenges are addressed, what tangible, specific benefits might arise?
  • Who, or what, will benefit from taking action, how does this relate to your audience?

_items.title: Need questions
_items.body:
This is the bit when you explain how your research is helping:
  • What are you doing or proposing to do to help address this problem or opportunity?
  • Why is your research important or unique?
  • Why are you credible to help resolve this issue?

title: Refine your research story
body: Asking the right S.P.I.N. questions is key to being able to understand your audience, your key message/s and the relevance of your research. However, can you answer the S.P.I.N questions when communicating your research? Select the S.P.I.N. framework document from the Resources menu. This provides you with some examples to get you thinking of how can apply S.P.I.N to your research. Then take some time to reflect and refine your own research story. Visit your CDP to complete the activity: Your research S.P.I.N.

title: The sticky principles
body: How do you make your message memorable? The book, <cite>Made to Stick</cite>, by brothers Chip and Dan Heath explains that making your communication stickier is about applying six principles or traits.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Simple
_items.body:
The core concept and message.

"Saying something short is not the mission – sound bites are not the ideal. Proverbs are the ideal. We must create ideas that are both simple and profound. The Golden Rule (do unto others as you would have them do unto you) is the ultimate model of simplicity: a one-sentence statement so profound that an individual could spend a lifetime learning to follow it."

_items.title: Unexpected
_items.body:
Grab their attention by using the element of surprise.

"How do we get our audience to pay attention to our ideas, and how do we maintain their interest when we need time to get the ideas across? We need to violate people's expectations."

_items.title: Concrete
_items.body:
Can the idea be grasped and remembered?

"Naturally sticky ideas are full of concrete images – ice-filled bathtubs, apples with razors – because our brains are wired to remember concrete data. In proverbs, abstract truths are often encoded in concrete language: "A bird in hand is worth two in the bush."

_items.title: Credible
_items.body:
Will they believe it?

"Sticky ideas have to carry their own credentials. We need ways to help people test our ideas for themselves – a "try before you buy" philosophy for the world of ideas."

_items.title: Emotional
_items.body:
Let people see the importance of your idea.

"How do we get people to care about our ideas? We make them feel something."

_items.title: Stories
_items.body:
Use narratives to empower people.

"How do we get people to act on our ideas? We tell stories. Firefighters naturally swap stories after every fire, and by doing so they multiply their experience."

title: Making it sticky
body: Consider how you can make your communication stickier. What can you do to develop credibility? How can you make people stand up and notice? Let's see one approach.
instruction: Select Play to hear some tips.

title: The key to sticky success
body:
"The Heath brothers have taught me that if anyone is going to "get" my idea – need it, buy it, fund it, use it – I need to radically shorten my elevator pitch. No more pretending that every building's a skyscraper. I can live in a world of complexity, and my theory of change can and should mirror the system I am working to change, but I'd better talk about it in a way that leaves my target wanting more, not less. Just because I have a theory of change doesn't mean I have to wear it on my sleeve."

Judith Samuelson (2007), Review: Made to Stick, Stanford Social Innovation Review.

Select 'Made to stick' from the Resources menu to learn more about how you can make an idea, concept or theory more memorable or interesting.

Authentic communication is an open and two-way conversation. It's about creating a climate of trust, where our voice is heard and our opinion is respected. Being an authentic speaker helps you establish rapport, cement relationships and enhance communication. Select the arrow to hear what people think about being authentic.

I think the bar is higher these days in terms of audience expectations of authenticity.

Shawn Ryan

Authenticity is absolutely the key to a great tweet.

Dick Costolo

I had no idea that being your authentic self could make me as rich as I've become. If I had, I'd have done it a lot earlier.

Oprah Winfrey

Always be a first-rate version of yourself and not a second-rate version of someone else.

Judy Garland

title: Becoming authentic
body: Authentic communicators understand themselves and they understand what motivates others. They are willing to be flexible with their communication style to meet their goals, as well as to help others meet their goals. What can you do to become an authentic speaker?
instruction: Select Play to hear from our expert.

title: What should you avoid?
body: We've talked about good communicators, but what shouldn't you do? In an article titled, 'How to pitch a brilliant idea' Kimberly Elsbach describes four stereotypical communicators that typically fail to connect and could be regarded as inauthentic – communicators that tend to kill ideas.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: The robot
_items.body: Presents in a formulaic way, as if they're repeating a memorised script or recipe.

_items.title: The pushover
_items.body: Someone who walks away from their ideas. For example, "I could change it to green, but if you don't like that, I could do it in yellow."

_items.title: The charity case
_items.body: Someone who's desperate for a job or pleading for an opportunity.

_items.title: The used-car salesman
_items.body: The person who's overly insistent and fails to listen to feedback.

title: What should you do?
body: You're preparing to present at a conference and want to make sure you're authentic. Which of the following will help?
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Think about what your listeners might be feeling.
Focus not on what you want to say but on why your message is important.
Focus on how you feel about the message.
Focus on your audience's motivators and priorities.
Put yourself in the audience's shoes.

_feedback.correct: That's right. All these techniques will help you deliver an authentic message. Your message should include four powerful aims: to be open, to connect, to be passionate and to listen. Select the article 'How to become an authentic speaker' from the Resources menu to explore these and other techniques in more detail. Then visit your CDP to complete the activity: Keeping it real.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. All these techniques will help you deliver an authentic message. Your message should include four powerful aims: to be open, to connect, to be passionate and to listen. Select the article 'How to become an authentic speaker' from the Resources menu to explore these and other techniques in more detail. Then visit your CDP to complete the activity: Keeping it real.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. All these techniques will help you deliver an authentic message. Your message should include four powerful aims: to be open, to connect, to be passionate and to listen. Select the article 'How to become an authentic speaker' from the Resources menu to explore these and other techniques in more detail. Then visit your CDP to complete the activity: Keeping it real.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Styles of talking
body: What's linguistic style? In 'The power of talk: who gets heard and why', Deborah Tannen explores linguistic style and how it impacts the way you connect. She refers to linguistic style as a person's characteristic speaking pattern, which includes various features. Next we'll look at how we need to adapt our style, but for now let's look at what the styles are.
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: Sharing credit
_items.body: Uses "we" rather than "I" to describe personal accomplishments. Why? "I" can seem too self-promotional.

_items.title: Acting modestly
_items.body: Downplays their certainty in the material being presented. Why? Confident behaviour can be perceived as too boastful.

_items.title: Asking questions
_items.body: Frequently asks questions. Why? Questions help the speaker generate knowledge.

_items.title: Apologising
_items.body: Apologises frequently. Why? Apologies express concern for others.

_items.title: Giving feedback
_items.body: Discusses weaknesses only after first identifying strengths. Why? Buffering criticism saves face for the individual receiving feedback.

_items.title: Avoiding verbal opposition
_items.body: Avoids challenging others' ideas and hedges when stating own ideas. Why? Verbal opposition signals destructive fighting.

_items.title: Managing up
_items.body: Avoids talking up achievements in front of people with more seniority. Why? Emphasising achievements to people higher-up is often perceived as boasting.

_items.title: Being indirect
_items.body: Speaks indirectly rather than bluntly when telling subordinates what to do. Why? Blatantly directing others is too bossy.

title: The consequences
body: Reflect on styles of talking and why people use them when communicating. What's the best way to communicate? There's no one best way. In one situation and with a particular person, a particular style may make sense. In another situation and with a different audience, it could be disastrous. Consider the following situations and reflect on what the audience may think of the speaker.
instruction: Select your response from the options below and select Submit.

_items.text: James is presenting to his research team and is asking a lot of questions.
Lisa avoids challenging other's ideas when discussing her findings.
Mark needs his research team to make a change, but is being indirect in his requests.

_feedback.correct: That's right. Asking questions frequently may make you appear ignorant to others; but if you fail to ask the right questions valuable knowledge remains buried. Not sticking up for your ideas may make your ideas look weak and not credible. Being indirect, when directness is required, shows a lack of assertiveness and clear thinking. People may conclude your directives are unimportant. Your style will be influenced by the situation, the people involved, the culture and your own experience. Select 'The power of talk' article from the Resources Menu to delve into the importance of linguistic style.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Asking questions frequently may make you appear ignorant to others; but if you fail to ask the right questions valuable knowledge remains buried. Not sticking up for your ideas may make your ideas look weak and not credible. Being indirect, when directness is required, shows a lack of assertiveness and clear thinking. People may conclude your directives are unimportant. Your style will be influenced by the situation, the people involved, the culture and your own experience. Select 'The power of talk' article from the Resources Menu to delve into the importance of linguistic style.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Asking questions frequently may make you appear ignorant to others; but if you fail to ask the right questions valuable knowledge remains buried. Not sticking up for your ideas may make your ideas look weak and not credible. Being indirect, when directness is required, shows a lack of assertiveness and clear thinking. People may conclude your directives are unimportant. Your style will be influenced by the situation, the people involved, the culture and your own experience. Select 'The power of talk' article from the Resources Menu to delve into the importance of linguistic style.

title: Considering diversity
body: One of the barriers to effective communication is not considering the cultural, personal and social differences of your audience. Diversity matters, and should be taken into account when thinking about potential audiences and how you communicate. The key to communicating effectively with culturally and linguistically diverse audiences is to be flexible.
instruction: Select play

title: Is persuasion important?
body: Do you need to persuade others? You may need to persuade your confirmation panel that your research is viable. You may want to convince people to participate in a survey or focus group. What if you need access to research infrastructure or you need someone to give you an opportunity (be that a grant, job, etc.)? These are all situations where the power of persuasion is needed. Let's hear how the power of persuasion can work.
instruction: Select play

title: The steps to being persuasive
body: Professor Jay Conger, an expert in leadership and communication, wrote about being persuasive in his article 'The necessary art of persuasion'. According to Conger, persuasive communication involves four steps.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Establishing credibility
_items.body: Credibility is based on your expertise and relationships. This is your chance to 'earn the right'! You may want to use a brief self-introduction that establishes your credibility. Some people struggle with this – they interpret it as big noting themselves. Keep it simple and with the formality of the occasion – it will certainly help.

_items.title: Framing goals on common ground
_items.body: Take the time to look for shared advantages when you describe your position. Find interests or outcomes that overlap and explore those in your message. Point to areas where there are mutual advantages and look for a shared higher purpose.

_items.title: Vividly reinforcing your position
_items.body: Make your evidence and data more compelling via examples, stories and metaphors. Support your message and provide evidence to back up what you're saying.

_items.title: Connecting emotionally
_items.body: Emotional awareness means being attuned to the emotional messages being conveyed in a communication. These are not only with the words being spoken but the way they are delivered. It's about adjusting your own emotional tone to match each audience's ability to receive your message.

title: Persuasive language
body: We use persuasive language to convince others to agree with our facts, share our values, accept our argument and conclusions and adopt our way of thinking. Reflect on the persuasive language techniques below. Which do you think sound more persuasive?
instruction: Select your response from the options below and select Submit.

_items.text: Be specific.

_options.text: 90% of people see results in 2 weeks.
Results can be seen in 2 weeks.

_items.text: Be positive.

_options.text: Failure to act on the recommendations will...

_items.text: Use positive framing.

_options.text: I don't know much about this industry.
Your industry is intriguing to me.

_feedback.correct: That's right. By adopting a positive tone and positively framing your message you put your audience in a receptive frame of mind. Great communicators use language to create mental pictures and stir emotions. Being specific and clear helps to persuade people to part with their money, make a strategic decision or generally shake things up. What steps will you take? Select the article 'The necessary art of persuasion' from the Resources menu to delve more into persuasive techniques. Then open your CDP to complete the activity: The persuasive challenge.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. By adopting a positive tone and positively framing your message you put your audience in a receptive frame of mind. Great communicators use language to create mental pictures and stir emotions. Being specific and clear helps to persuade people to part with their money, make a strategic decision or generally shake things up. What steps will you take? Select the article 'The necessary art of persuasion' from the Resources menu to delve more into persuasive techniques. Then open your CDP to complete the activity: The persuasive challenge.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. By adopting a positive tone and positively framing your message you put your audience in a receptive frame of mind. Great communicators use language to create mental pictures and stir emotions. Being specific and clear helps to persuade people to part with their money, make a strategic decision or generally shake things up. What steps will you take? Select the article 'The necessary art of persuasion' from the Resources menu to delve more into persuasive techniques. Then open your CDP to complete the activity: The persuasive challenge.

title: It's in your hands
body: In today's world, career paths are becoming more flexible and diverse and new opportunities are appearing. Be prepared to take advantage of such opportunities by developing your communication skills. It's a critical factor in your career success. What can you do to improve your communication skills?
instruction: Select play.

title: Devise a plan
body: Ultimately, having a plan or strategy is about two things: what's important and what's worth doing. What activities can you add to your communication plan?
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Observe others
_items.body: Keep an eye out for and attend talks and presentations. Make use of accessible talks online (e.g. www.ted.com). Reflect on what presenters did well, why their communication worked or didn't work and what you can incorporate in your future communication approach.

_items.title: Learn from experts
_items.body: Read books and articles on effective communication (e.g. <cite>Make it Stick</cite> by Chip and Dan Heath or Harvard Business Review's '10 must reads on communication'). Find out about other communication courses and online resources offered by the University. Seek out vodcasts or podcasts.

_items.title: Explore communication frameworks
_items.body: Build on what you've already learnt in this course. Spend more time using S.P.I.N. or other communication frameworks that will help with your communication flow.

_items.title: Have a go
_items.body: Actively seek out opportunities to present and communicate your ideas to both academic and non-academic audiences. You may want to participate in the Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition. Remember, practice doesn't always make perfect, but it sure helps!

title: Plan for the present. Prepare for the future.
displayTitle: Plan for the present. Prepare for the future.
body: Developing your communication capabilities will enhance your research and prepare you for life after your degree. Ask yourself, "What do I need to work on to be a better communicator?"
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select submit.

_items.text: Use persuasion techniques.
Make my communication stickier.
Use a communication framework, like S.P.I.N.
Practise good communication techniques.
Use various communication channels.
Work on connecting to my audience.

_feedback.correct: These are just a few suggestions we've covered in this course. Time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better communicator. Identify a set of clear actions you can take to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to practise your communication techniques by participating in a Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition. Open your CDP to complete your CDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.

_incorrect.final: These are just a few suggestions we've covered in this course. Time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better communicator. Identify a set of clear actions you can take to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to practise your communication techniques by participating in a Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition. Open your CDP to complete your CDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.

_partlyCorrect.final: These are just a few suggestions we've covered in this course. Time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better communicator. Identify a set of clear actions you can take to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to practise your communication techniques by participating in a Three Minute Thesis (3MT) competition. Open your CDP to complete your CDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.
